content:
Thunderbird has limited built-in import capabilities, which are described here:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-import

In particular, and strangely enough, Thunderbird doesn't have built-in import/export capabilities for individual mailboxes, but that functionality can be added to Thunderbird by installing an add-on (extension) called ImportExportTools:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/
creator: DavidGG

content:
There is an Automatically delete junk mail older than setting in the account Junk Settings. You probably have that checked.

You may also want to right-click on the Junk folder, choose Properties, select the Retention Policy tab and make sure that's not configured to delete old messages from the folder.

Blocco totale, senza altre informazioni purtroppo non dice nulla. Prova a fornire qualche dettaglio:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo

  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

ps:/support.mozilla.com e' una community per gli utenti del software Mozilla. Non e' un supporto tecnico e gli utenti che vi partecipano sono tutti volontari
creator: @next

content: Don't use email accounts that no longer exist on the server for archiving purposes. Use Local Folders for that instead and organise your mail there however you wish independently of any email account you may have.
creator: DavidGG

content:
If any of the accounts use 'app' passwords (such as required by Gmail), the app password will not work on new PC, as app passwords are designed to work on only the original PC. If that is your situation, you need to get new app passwords for new PC.

If that is not the case, it may just be that there was an error in copying from old to new. Steps for that are below: - exit thunderbird on both PCs - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media - paste the thunderbird folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming on new pc. This will prompt to overwrite the profile there. Allow it.
creator: davidsk

content: "Archiv" ist kein Konto, sondern nur ein "Ordner" in einem Konto. Falls das GMX Konto ein IMAP Konto ist, musst du den Ordner "Archiv" wahrscheinlich erst mal "abonnieren": R-Klick auf den Kontennamen > Abonnieren.... öffnet eine Liste mit sämtlichen Ordnern und Unterordnern des Kontos. Da suchst du nach "Archiv" (oder auch englisch "Archives") und machst ein Kreuz, gegebenenfalls auch bei dessen Unterordnern. Und dann das OK nicht vergessen...

content: Since part of the screenshot is blurry, I must make assumptions. My guess is that is a unified view on top. If so, the appearance of the same account lower down would be because that account has one or more folders that are not unified. That is, folders with names that are not used in folders of the other accounts. The intent of Thunderbird is to make all folders viewable. When a user selects the unified view, Thunderbird then adds the account again to display the other folders.
creator: davidsk

content:
What david said, but not exactly. You're using Unified Folders view. Thunderbird only unifies the special folders that have a pre-defined role, not any other custom folders each of your mail accounts may have. So even if you had the same folder in multiple accounts, if that's not one of the special folders that Thunderbird knows about, it will still not unify them… which means it must display them some other way… and that other way is the same way it would use to display them if you were using the All Folders view, i.e. under the account each of those folders belongs to, below the unified folders.

Moreover, depending on your account settings, you may have special folders that you would expect to be unified not unified and hence appear separately under the corresponding account. This may happen, for example, if you have a Spam folder on the server, but have told Thunderbird to store junk mail in a folder called Junk. The Spam folder won't be treated as a special folder by Thunderbird in that case, and hence appear under the account instead of under the unified Junk folder.

Some people find all of this quite confusing and prefer to use All Folders view mode for consistency. I personally prefer Unified Folders, but that may be because I find that view consistent as well… once you understand how it all works… :)
creator: DavidGG

The protocol is you read KB articles that might be relevant to your problem and if you cannot find the solution there provide information that might help troubleshoot it… :P

What does "cannot send" mean? What happens when you try to send? Do you get an error message or what? If you do, post a screenshot of the error message you get.

Which is your email provider? Post a screenshot of your outgoing (SMTP) server settings, so we may verify they're correct.

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages

content:
If automatic account configuration doesn't work, you have to switch to Configure manually, figure what your account settings should be and manually configure the account according to those settings. Your email provider should have told you what the right settings are supposed to be, but if you don't know, you may try with these:

https://www.postbox-inc.com/setup/email-settings/access-blueyonder-co-uk-via-imap-smtp
creator: DavidGG

https://www.virginmedia.com/help/broadband/manage-email-settings

P.S. Your picture exposes the account password, which should be obscured in a public forum.
creator: sfhowes

content:
A VPN generally interferes with authentication of mail accounts, so it's advisable to either disable the VPN during mail connections, or add TB in 'split tunneling' settings.

https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/products/vpn/resource-center/split-tunneling-with-mozilla-vpn/
creator: sfhowes
